high_relevance.description: Examines how social structure and relationships create opportunities and constraints for individuals and organizations
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Directly addresses RQ1 by explaining how network position, tie strength, and structural holes affect progression from periphery to core
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Can model network metrics (centrality, density, clustering) as stocks/flows affecting knowledge access and promotion likelihood
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Quantifies social capital accumulation in OSS careers; reveals network bottlenecks in progression pathways

high_relevance.description: Motivation theory focusing on innate psychological needs for autonomy, competence, and relatedness
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Explains motivational drivers for progression (RQ1) and provides framework for designing effective interventions (RQ2)
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Can model motivation as stock influenced by autonomy support, competence feedback, and relatedness events
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Links motivational dynamics to career progression; provides psychological foundation for intervention design

high_relevance.description: Argues that accidents are inevitable in complex, tightly-coupled systems due to interactive complexity
high_relevance.relevance_to_rqs: Directly addresses RQ3 by explaining why vulnerabilities emerge in complex socio-technical systems like OSS
high_relevance.relevance_to_model: Can model system complexity and coupling as variables affecting vulnerability introduction and detection rates
high_relevance.phd_contribution: Applies NAT to software security context; reveals systemic rather than individual causes of vulnerabilities

adjacent_opportunities.description: Examines how organizations detect and correct errors through single-loop and double-loop learning
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: OSS communities are organizations but rarely studied as such; focuses on collective rather than individual learning
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Treats OSS communities as learning organizations with defensive routines and learning disabilities
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Explains why some communities fail to learn from security incidents; reveals organizational barriers to improvement

adjacent_opportunities.description: Treats both human and non-human actors as equally important in network formation and stability
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Extends beyond human social networks to include technical artifacts in the progression pathway
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Reveals how tools, bots, documentation, and code artifacts enable or constrain career progression
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Shows how socio-technical networks shape career paths; explains role of non-human actors in vulnerability introduction

adjacent_opportunities.description: Work stress model where job demands require effort while job resources help achieve goals and reduce demands
adjacent_opportunities.why_adjacent: Applies organizational psychology to volunteer contexts; focuses on burnout and engagement dynamics
adjacent_opportunities.novel_angle: Explains attrition and burnout in OSS careers as function of demands/resources imbalance
adjacent_opportunities.phd_contribution: Predicts points of developer dropout; provides framework for sustainable community design

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: OSS communities as ecosystems with pioneer species, climax communities, and disturbance responses
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Predicts community maturity stages and vulnerability to disruption during transitions
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Provides powerful metaphors for community resilience and vulnerability patterns across lifecycle

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: Medical residency as intensive socialization from novice to expert with formal/informal learning
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Reveals hidden curriculum and identity transformation aspects of OSS career progression
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Explains identity formation and professional values adoption missing from current learning theories

cross_domain_inspiration.parallel: Collective problem-solving in decentralized systems like ant colonies or bird flocks
cross_domain_inspiration.transfer_potential: Models how decentralized coordination emerges and fails in OSS communities
cross_domain_inspiration.rationale: Offers novel perspective on collective code quality assurance and vulnerability detection

phd_strategy.rationale: These three theories directly address the core gaps: SNT explains social dynamics of progression, SDT provides motivational foundation for interventions, and NAT offers systemic perspective on vulnerabilities. All are well-established with empirical support and can be effectively modeled in system dynamics.
phd_strategy.integration_strategy: Use SNT to extend Communities of Practice by quantifying social capital; apply SDT to enrich SECI model with motivational drivers; employ NAT to complement existing learning theories with systemic risk perspective. Create integrated SD model showing how social networks × motivation × system complexity affect career progression and security outcomes.
phd_strategy.expected_impact: Transforms the research from descriptive to explanatory; enables predictive modeling of career pathways and vulnerability risks; provides theoretically-grounded intervention design principles for OSS communities.
